author: @TheSportsEagle
title: Wallabies Oust Pumas
text: @TheSportsEagle 0 Comment An Adam Ashley-Cooper hat-trick helped send Australia into its fourth Rugby World Cup final, as the Wallabies beat Argentina 29-15 in a tense semi-final at Twickenham on Sunday . The Australians have set up an epic showdown with New Zealand at Twickenham next Saturday in the first decider between the two nations, with a record third Webb Ellis Cupon offer for the victor. The three-try performance, which also came with 58 metres and two clean breaks, earned the 113-Test veteran Ashley-Cooper man of the match honours and helped stave off a spirited performance from Los Pumas who once again chanced their arm in attack. The first came in the 10th, with Ashley-Cooper finishing a pass from flyhalf Bernard Foley to cross in the right hand corner. He had his second before the half was complete, after the Aussies capitalised on an Argentine yellow card, finding themselves with a four-on-two overlap out wide. It was a Matt Giteau cut-out pass that put him over in the left corner to stretch the two-time world champions’ early lead. An electrifying run from Drew Mitchell completed the trifecta, sending a long pass to his opposite winger after making a burst down the left flank and running across field beating five defenders, giving Ashley-Cooper an opportunity to put it down under the posts and seal the match for the men in gold. Attack was clearly the priority of the day with both sides passing the ball around but it was Michael Cheika’s charges who had more composure near their try line. It took less than two minutes for the men from Down Under’s running play to bear fruit against the South Americans, when unlikely scorer Rob Simmons snatched an intercept from the pass of flyhalf Nicolas Sanchez. It was just Simmons’ second try in the gold jersey through 59 appearances and it ignited Cheika’s charges in a frenetic start, before Ashley-Cooper’s brace provided a 19-9 half-time lead. Twice in the first half the Oceania side was under pressure but desperate tackles from Bernard Foley and Will Genia cut off strong runs by Daniel Hourcade’s men in the Australian 22. The reunion of Michael Hooper and David Pocock as a starting combination proved destructive for Australia, as they dominated at the breakdown to finish the match with 10 turnovers. Pocock shrugged off any doubt over his fitness, finishing the night with four turnovers, leading all comers and continuing to stretch his overall tournament lead, while also making 13 tackles for the night. The Wallabies’ scrum was put under pressure early with the Latin Americans earning the first two scrum penalties, one of those deep in Aussie attacking territory, but overall the Aussies were able to match Hourcade’s men at the set piece. Scott Fardy was a force in defence finishing with 16 tackles while lock Kane Douglas (14 tackles) once again made his impact felt. The Rugby Championship holders lacked in discipline and a near-perfect kicking record from Sanchez punished them for their mistakes, as the men in gold conceded 12 penalties to Argentina’s 6. The gold jerseys’ defence withstood a late Argentine surge, once again showing their heart as Los Pumas hammered the Aussie line, in a match where Cheika’s charges made 142 tackles to just 95 from their opponents. Captain Stephen Moore set the tone for his team before being replaced in the 58th minute, pulling off a critical tackle on halfway as the South Americans held attacking momentum, one of nine in the match. The Wallabies will now meet the All Blacks in the Rugby World Cup 2015 final on Saturday 31 October , while Argentina will play South Africa in the bronze medal match on Friday. Photo credit: Rodrigo Vergara/UAR
